Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2013 08:36PM Sandymomto3 wrote: Cheryl....second opinions are never a bad idea. My tumor was much larger than yours and no chemo for me. The decision can be very difficult. My Oncotype is a 13... And my chance of reoccurrence is low. I'd like to also point out using an American cancer society q and a before my MRI, they discovered my natural chance of being diagnosed was less than 10%. I think I need not visit Vegas anytime soon. Thoughts and prayers with you during these days of tough choices.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2013 08:21PM Sandymomto3 wrote: mmvh....I am currently in that trial. I had 3 positive nodes. I was computer randomized to the non chemo group. After lots of thought and discussion I entered the next step of the trial. My Oncotype is a 13. 18 and below is deemed low. Not sure where you live and what medical care/facilities you have access to, but a second opinion if you are unsure is never a bad idea. These boards are full of wonderful ladies...tons of information and support.
Posts.Title: oncotype:16, (hormone driven w/one 3mm lymph node mmvh Martessa2553

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2013 08:51PM Sandymomto3 wrote: Well had a few moments and thought I would check in. My lumectomy and sentinel node biopsy was yesterday. Did not find the injection for the sentinel node as bad as I had inticipated the radiologist was very fast. Received sedation and a regional block, once in the OR the surgeon said she felt one or the other of them wasn't working well so they decided general was the way to go. Once in recovery I can say it was the regional block had not taken because I was already feeling pain. Not extreme, but I wasn't expecting any due to a block form12-18 hrs of pain relief. Surgeon didnt offer a lot post op to my family or me. Says she is hopeful she captured all of the tumor but of course no one has microscopic eyes. The area had some smaller moon shaped areas nearby and she feels at this point she has taken all she can in a lumectomy. First 3 nodes were positive so more were taken, but she didn't answer how many. My concerns of course are the level of node involvement and the need for more surgery if it wasn't all removed. She felt strongly going into yesterday I was a good candidate for a lumectomy based on the size 3cm, and location approximately 2 o'clock. Should have a path report in 48-72 hrs. Drain til follow up appointment Tuesday next week. I have enjoyed this board and reading stories of others....so many inspirational stories here. Prayers for the others in this September group as well as the many others waging on in the fight of their lives.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2013 02:48AM Sandymomto3 wrote: Tressaliz...I too am having my lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy on the 9th. I will add you to my prayers. It has been almost a month since my diagnosis as well. At first just hearing the words breast cancer took my breath away. I understand how you feel about surgery, I just want that part over so we know in more detail what we are facing.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2013 06:29PM Sandymomto3 wrote: Jo6202.... Are you having the Oncotype DX test? Set backs are no fun. Really wanted the breast conservation surgery not a mx....breast surgeon said I was a good candidate so we moved forward. Tumor sight even with pre surgery mri ended up larger than she thought, but thankful for clean margins. Having some arm swelling, very minor. Hoping it's not a problem brewing. Ready for the next step.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2013 04:54PM Sandymomto3 wrote: schoolcounselor...second opinions never a bad idea. I have agreed to enter a clinical trial that is studying chemo in the 1-3 node positive er/pr+ cancer area. Oncologist has already cautioned me if I am not randomized for chemo people will tell me I'm nuts. Ultimately everyone makes choices best for them. I've enjoyed this website and boards....so much good advise and information. Always go with your first instinct and if that's for a second opinion I say go for it. Wishing you a week of continued recovery.

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2013 08:41PM Sandymomto3 wrote: summer...our surgery dates are similar....although you've had double the surgery i had. I am not having chemo and have had my MO amd RO appointments. My radiation begins next week. Will see MO again after rads, and will get my prescription then for tamoxifen. He prefers to wait til after rads due to any side effects etc. Hope your onco score is low :)

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2014 07:21AM Sandymomto3 wrote: I had an axilary node dissection in September 2013.   Pain from the surgery which included a lumectomy was never terrible.   Only used 2 prescription pain pills after discharge from hospital.  Advil worked fine for that for my post op discomforts.  Second opinions are never a bad idea if you are unsure.
Posts.Title: Axillary Lymph Node Dissection annabananas Batesburg

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2013 02:09AM Sandymomto3 wrote: Lee1963... Had my lumpectomy and node dissection on 9/9. I think the wire is used for lumps that are small and possibly not felt well physically by you or your doctor. Dye injection isn't fun, but it was very quick and that helped. Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2013 02:19AM Sandymomto3 wrote: cjc...I had a lumpectomy with an axillary dissection. Hands down most of my discomfort has been the arm pit area. I am 4 weeks out and still not 100%. Can't sleep on that side and it's just uncomfortable. Keep the faith, this too shall pass.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2013 08:33PM Sandymomto3 wrote: Good morning. I had a nerve block on Monday 9/9 for a lumectomy and sentinel node biopsy that turned into an axillary node dissection. Before administering the block, they give your some sedation to relax you. I've had children and epidural injections and i would say its similar. No pain with the injections, and the sedation makes you a bit drowsy. In my actual case once to the OR, where the plan was conscious sedation it was felt by the anesthesia doc that the block had not taken. I was already semi asleep and have no memory of anything, but general ended up being used. So, the only negative was no 12-18 hrs of pain relief. Hope your surgery goes well...wishing you the best.
